learning_outcomes.description: Compare different philosophical frameworks for understanding what and how science tells us about reality.
Evaluate how different scientific theories represent reality, and the assumptions about the world and scientific inquiry on which those representations depend.
Recognise the role played by scientific representations in scientific discovery and practice, as well as public engagement with science.
Engage in contemporary debates about the scientific picture of the world in a critical and informed way.

assessments.task_description:
Students are assessed on their participation and contribution to class discussions and engagement with written tasks completed in tutorials in up to 8 out of 10 weeks.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Essay on a topic from the first half of the course.

A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial

Tutorials will run from Weeks 2 to 6, and then from Weeks 8 to 12.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Tutorial Tutorials will run from Weeks 2 to 6, and then from Weeks 8 to 12.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction: many scientific pictures, one world?

General introduction to the course and subject matter: the idea that the sciences offer multiple 'pictures' of the world, raising the question of what scientific theories actually say about reality and where their limits lie.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Introduction: many scientific pictures, one world? General introduction to the course and subject matter: the idea that the sciences offer multiple 'pictures' of the world, raising the question of what scientific theories actually say about reality and where their limits lie.

learning_activities.topic:
How do theories tell us about the world?

We compare philosophical approaches to how theories relate to reality: Do they describe reality? Or just organise data? Do they predict phenomena? Or should they also explain how the world works?


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: How do theories tell us about the world?
learning_activities.topic_description: How do theories tell us about the world? We compare philosophical approaches to how theories relate to reality: Do they describe reality? Or just organise data? Do they predict phenomena? Or should they also explain how the world works?

learning_activities.topic:
Is a unified scientific view of our world possible?

We examine whether the sciences can, or should, yield a unified picture of the world, and how apparently competing scientific pictures can be compatible, complementary, or genuinely in tension.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Is a unified scientific view of our world possible?
learning_activities.topic_description: Is a unified scientific view of our world possible? We examine whether the sciences can, or should, yield a unified picture of the world, and how apparently competing scientific pictures can be compatible, complementary, or genuinely in tension.

learning_activities.topic:
What is scientific explanation?

We develop an interventionist, graph-based account of scientific explanation and use it to analyse what causal models represent, what assumptions they embed, and what limitations they face.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: What is scientific explanation? We develop an interventionist, graph-based account of scientific explanation and use it to analyse what causal models represent, what assumptions they embed, and what limitations they face.

learning_activities.topic:
Levels of organisation and explanatory diversity across sciences

We learn how explanations differ across domains and levels (mechanistic, historical, functional, computational) and how interlevel relations shape what different sciences can legitimately be taken to say.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Levels of organisation and explanatory diversity across sciences
learning_activities.topic_description: Levels of organisation and explanatory diversity across sciences We learn how explanations differ across domains and levels (mechanistic, historical, functional, computational) and how interlevel relations shape what different sciences can legitimately be taken to say.

learning_activities.topic:
Is life more than physics?

We consider whether biological phenomena are fully captured by purely physical descriptions, applying what we have learned about levels of organisation and explanation to clarify what the biological picture adds.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Is life more than physics? We consider whether biological phenomena are fully captured by purely physical descriptions, applying what we have learned about levels of organisation and explanation to clarify what the biological picture adds.

learning_activities.topic:
Evolution, function, and fitness: what is the evolutionary picture?

We analyse what evolutionary theory claims about living systems, how talk about biological function should be interpreted, and what kind of theoretical quantity 'fitness' is supposed to be.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Evolution, function, and fitness: what is the evolutionary picture?
learning_activities.topic_description: Evolution, function, and fitness: what is the evolutionary picture? We analyse what evolutionary theory claims about living systems, how talk about biological function should be interpreted, and what kind of theoretical quantity 'fitness' is supposed to be.

learning_activities.topic:
Are species and genes real? If so, what are they?

We develop a framework for thinking about scientific classification and kinds, then apply it to debates about the reality and nature of species and genes across biological contexts.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: Are species and genes real? If so, what are they?
learning_activities.topic_description: Are species and genes real? If so, what are they? We develop a framework for thinking about scientific classification and kinds, then apply it to debates about the reality and nature of species and genes across biological contexts.

learning_activities.topic:
Scientific psychology and folk psychology

We investigate whether scientific psychology vindicates, revises, replaces, or eliminates everyday explanations in terms of beliefs and desires, and what psychological theories thereby commit us to as real.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Scientific psychology and folk psychology We investigate whether scientific psychology vindicates, revises, replaces, or eliminates everyday explanations in terms of beliefs and desires, and what psychological theories thereby commit us to as real.

learning_activities.topic:
Are mental disorders brain disorders?

We evaluate competing accounts of what mental disorders are and whether they are best understood as brain disorders, with attention to levels of explanation; when we use a diagnostic label, are we naming something that exists as a unified phenomenon, or are we imposing a classificatory scheme that serves certain explanatory and practical purposes.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Are mental disorders brain disorders? We evaluate competing accounts of what mental disorders are and whether they are best understood as brain disorders, with attention to levels of explanation; when we use a diagnostic label, are we naming something that exists as a unified phenomenon, or are we imposing a classificatory scheme that serves certain explanatory and practical purposes.

learning_activities.topic:
Can biological evolution explain social development?

We critically examine evolutionary explanations of human behaviour and social phenomena, focusing on when it is okay to apply evolutionary theory, what counts as good evidence, and the risks of overextending a theory beyond what it can represent.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Can biological evolution explain social development? learning_activities.topic:
Chemical reactions, bonds, and substances

We examine how chemistry represents the world through concepts such as substances, bonds, and reaction mechanisms, and what these representations commit us to about chemical kinds, explanation, and the relationship between chemical practice and underlying physical theory.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Chemical reactions, bonds, and substances We examine how chemistry represents the world through concepts such as substances, bonds, and reaction mechanisms, and what these representations commit us to about chemical kinds, explanation, and the relationship between chemical practice and underlying physical theory.

learning_activities.topic:
The limits of scientific representations

The course concludes by drawing together the semester’s themes to articulate the limits of scientific 'pictures': how is it that what theories can genuinely be taken to say is constrained?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
